Spinal decompression primarily works by reducing tension in the erector spinae, hamstrings, glutes, and core muscles, creating space between vertebrae, and improving circulation, not directly building muscle, but allowing them to function better. The movement pattern involves controlled stretching (flexion, extension, lateral bending, rotation) to relieve pressure, often using variable pull-relax cycles to prevent muscle guarding, enhancing overall spinal mobility and stability when combined with strengthening exercises. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked (Indirectly & Supportively) 
Spinal decompression aims to relax muscles that guard the spine and promote healing in deep supportive tissues, rather than isolating them for strength training. 

• Spinal Stabilizers: Relieves tension in the erector spinae (longissimus, iliocostalis, spinalis) and deep multifidus, allowing them to function better. 
• Core Muscles: Reduces spasms and improves function in the abdominals and obliques, which support the spine. 
• Glutes & Hamstrings: Stretches tight hamstrings and piriformis, which can pull on the pelvis and lower back. [1, 4, 5, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns 
The therapy uses controlled, cyclical movements to achieve decompression. 

• Variable Tension: Instead of constant pulling (traction), decompression uses cycles of stretch and release to relax muscles and prevent guarding. 
• Spinal Elongation: Creates negative pressure to draw disc material back in and decompress nerve roots. 
• Flexion & Extension: Gentle forward (flexion) and backward (extension) bending movements. 
• Lateral Bending & Rotation: Some protocols incorporate side bending and twisting to target specific spinal segments. [3, 6, 9, 10, 11]  

How it Helps Muscles & Movement 

• Reduces Muscle Spasm & Guarding: The gentle stretching relaxes tight muscles that reflexively contract due to pain. 
• Improves Circulation: Creates suction to bring nutrients and oxygen to discs, aiding muscle recovery. 
• Restores Mobility: Allows for a greater range of motion (flexion, extension, etc.). 
• Foundation for Strengthening: By alleviating pain, it enables patients to perform targeted core and back exercises to build lasting stability. [1, 2, 3, 9, 10, 12]
